text: You can do it. Good book, some mindfulness, and a little pharmacological help :)
author: HillaryKelly

text: Only librarians understand censorship? What a snobbish way to handle this. I'm so happy to have interesting debates, but not to be talked down to when this is obviously an issue that a literary critic would be interested in/have some things to say about.
author: HillaryKelly

text: Just like some libraries have chosen to listen to mobs of Evangelist parents angry about sex in books...and many libraries haven't. That doesn't mean in the cases where the books were removed/not distributed that it *wasn't* censorship.
author: HillaryKelly

text: Except...they did tell the corporations (who are dependent upon them and their dollars), and the corporations did listen. Just bc this is a small group doesn't mean their power isn't outsized.
author: HillaryKelly

text: They had the power of the mob. That's a MASSIVE amount of power. If they *didn't* have power, those books wouldn't have been cancelled.
author: HillaryKelly

text: It's the definition of censorship. A small group of readers decides they are offended by something in a book and causes a ruckus to encourage/force the publishers to ensure the rest of the public won't see it.
author: HillaryKelly

text: The distinction there is ... censorship. There's a big difference between a book that's available but perhaps not widely praised/publicized/adored, etc, and a book that doesn't hit shelves b/c of a small band of early readers.
author: HillaryKelly

text: Hmmmm. You make a great point--I think what I was trying to say (poorly) is that that small segment of the market is wielding their power in such a way as to make themselves gatekeepers, even if they ought not be.
author: HillaryKelly

text: arguably*
author: HillaryKelly

text: I loved it. It's my first Brookner. I was somehow entirely in the dark about her genius until a month ago. Now I'm hoarding her books.
author: HillaryKelly

text: In the cases of these cancelled YA books the market very much *is* deciding what the market *can't* read, which is arguable just as important as deciding what we can.
author: HillaryKelly

text:
And yes, this comment is directed at the human man who tossed an alarming amount of pathetic shade my way in a Very Fancy Article.

But then I remembered I generate my own heat, and FOR ALL TIME old snobs have been desperately moaning as they're replaced.
